text: New Orleans may be best known for its
elixirs on Bourbon Street when the heart
of the French Quarter
chemists can find a different kind of
elixir the New Orleans pharmacy Museum
is a recreation of a 19th century
apothecary shop originally opened in
1823 by Lewis Jade's a fellow junior
America's first licensed pharmacist
inside the museum shelves and cabinets
are filled from Florida ceiling with
bottles and jars containing crude drugs
herbal medicines and blue powders 19th
century pharmacy in New Orleans was a
unique blend of European methods Native
American use of medicinal indigenous
plants and dose of African American
herbal medicine back then practitioners
would compound medicine from scratch
using plants minerals and animal insect
ingredients
Natha chandelier a tour guide for the
museum describes a few of the
fascinating relics that can be found in
the museum so here we have two species
jars which contain the raw materials
that a pharmacist would use to make
medicine so they have all sorts of
vegetable animal and also mineral
products in them and the shape of the
jars and often time indicates what's in
them so these larger ones we have down
here are some kind of completely
unprocessed materials there's more
square ones up there that had liquid in
them but there's all kinds of stuff in
these species jars because they were
really using a variety of different
ingredients in medicine so here's some
lichen there's definitely a lot of use
of herbal medicine in the 19th century
but at the same time a lot of more
chemical things we're starting to be
synthesized in laboratories and over the
course of the 19th century on medicine
came to look a lot more like it looks
nowadays in terms of a standard medicine
so here's some sulphur an example of a
mineral that was commonly used but so in
the 19th century they were using these
herbal remedies which are still used
today by herbalist
had been used for centuries prior to
that but also a lot of newer chemicals
that were being synthesized in
laboratories and a lot of the things
were are still used today a lot of
things were really beneficial that were
discovered but of course there was also
the use of very harmful chemicals like
mercury and arsenic and led things like
that there wasn't a lot of knowledge of
their injurious qualities so speaking
about animal products we have an example
of that here these are some little
greenish beetles which are labeled cam
chorus but are also known as Spanish Fly
they were popular as an aphrodisiac in
the nineteenth century but just caused
life-threatening inflammation it was not
a very good thing to take but there was
a lot of use of insect exoskeletons they
also have jars of shrimp crawfish things
like that they were all being used in
medicine if you missed the pharmacy
museum during his press ACS national
meeting don't worry you'll get another
chance when easiest returns to New
Orleans in the spring of 2018
